title: China Finally Snuffs Out a Beacon of Liberal Thought and Democracy
summary: Beijing's Unirule Institute, founded to promote economic liberalization and democracy, set to shut down after a quarter-century, citing government pressure. BEIJING-An independent Chinese think tank that has served as a rare bastion for liberal economic thought will shut down, citing government pressure as President Xi Jinping's campaign to silence dissent rolls on.

title: Brazil's Leader Spurns Amazon Fire Aid in Spat With Macron
summary: President says country will only accept $20 million package if French leader apologizes for calling Bolsonaro a liar. BRASÍLIA-Brazil's President Jair Bolsonaro threatened to refuse $20 million from Group of Seven countries to help fight fires in the Amazon rainforest unless French President Emmanuel Macron apologizes for calling him a liar about his commitment to the environment.

title: Peloton to Pursue Nasdaq Listing, Dual-Class Stock Structure in IPO

title: Meet the Biggest 'Stakeholders'
summary: The SEC brings some needed transparency to the proxy duopoly.. But the Securities and Exchange Commission is taking note of their influence and finally holding them accountable.

title: Hollywood Diversifies After Rebuke Over Racial and Gender Inequality

title: The SAT Changes Its Answer
summary: The College Board is right to drop plans for an 'adversity score.'. The educational establishment rarely reverses itself when it makes a mistake in the name of combating inequality. So the College Board deserves credit for its decision, announced Tuesday, to scrap plans for an "adversity score" to accompany students' SAT results. The metric would have increased cynicism about the inscrutable college-admissions game.

title: The Federal Reserve Resistance
summary: A recent official urges the central bank to help defeat Donald Trump.. Perhaps you've seen former Chairs of the Federal Reserve defending the central bank's independence and foreswearing all political intentions. Fair enough. But then what are we to make of former Fed monetary Vice Chair William Dudley's marker that the Fed should help defeat President Trump in 2020? That's the extraordinary message from the former, and perhaps future, Fed grandee in Bloomberg.

title: What Your College Orientation Won't Teach You
summary: Schools should try a less congratulatory and more honest approach.. Editor's note: This Future View is about freshman orientations at U.S. colleges. What role should the adversity that applicants face play in the college admissions process? Students should click here to submit opinions of fewer than 250 words before Sept. 3. The best responses will be published that night.

summary: Rather than expanding schools that help minority students, the mayor wants to shut them down.. But when you consider the state of public education in our inner cities, and the priorities of those in charge, it's hard to draw any other conclusion.

I've never had a sip, yet the sign was a passport to a parade of memories.

title: 'Ludicrous' Review: A Revolutionary Old Product
summary: For all its innovations-from battery power to computer-assisted driving-Tesla continues to emphasize its cars' speed, luxury and sex appeal.. Only Lamborghini and De Tomaso succeeded, though with small numbers of vehicles that were essentially handmade. Rare is the new marque that reaches mass production. That is, until Elon Musk and Tesla.

summary: President Rouhani steps back from a potential diplomatic opening as hard-liners warn against showing weakness. Iran's President Hassan Rouhani rejected the possibility of meeting with President Trump as long as the U.S. sanctioned his country, a day after both leaders appeared to be opening up to possible talks following months of heightened tensions.

summary: Department of Homeless Services says savings accounts will aid transition to permanent housing. New York City offers a free stay in its homeless shelters, but a newly proposed rule would require residents to save a share of their monthly income to use the housing.

title: Why Not 'Forever' Bonds for Federal Debt?
summary: Bonds that never mature might seem odd but have advantages and precedents.. Your editorial "A 100-Year Treasury?" (Aug, 23) encourages the U.S. Treasury Department to issue 50- and 100-year-maturity bonds while interest rates are unusually low. The Treasury should go further and issue "forever bonds" or "consols" to lock in low rates permanently.

title: Safe Haven Baby Boxes Have a Long History
summary: To shelter Paris's rising numbers of abandoned infants, St. Vincent DePaul instructed his confreres in charge of convents, hospices and orphanages to carve out baby compartments at the backs of their buildings.. The Safe Haven Baby Boxes described in "Boxes Provide Babies Safe Refuge" (U.S. News, Aug. 16) hark back to a system used by the 17th-century priest St. Vincent DePaul (1581-1660) to shelter Paris's rising number of abandoned infants. St. Vincent instructed his confreres in charge of convents, hospices and orphanages to carve out similar, adult-height baby compartments at the backs of their buildings, and to advertise their locations. When an outer sliding door was raised, the parent found a turntable platform inside. Once the baby was laid and the door closed, an inner door was raised by the nun or priest stationed in wait who rotated the table to position the baby for safe removal inside, replacing the child with a medal on a ribbon that contained a number. The parent could opt to reopen the outer door and retrieve the medal. Each infant was cataloged by age, gender and surrender location and tagged with a corresponding medal. Those leaving a child were encouraged to retain the medal so they one day could trace their loved one through St. Vincent's orphanage network.

title: Trump's Tarrif Wars Are Killing Farmers Like Me
summary: President Trump's idea of making us whole is to give us two and one-half cents per pound and acting like he is taking care of us. He is not.. Regarding your editorial "Cut the Trump Uncertainty Tax" (Aug. 22): As a walnut farmer in California, I must comment that President Trump's federal aid to affected small farms is a mere drop in the bucket. The losses farmers are experiencing due to our trade war is about 36 cents per pound of walnuts a year. My farm produces about two million pounds a year. President Trump's idea of making us whole is to give us two-and-one-half cents per pound and act like he is taking care of us. He is not.

title: Privately Owned Guns Deter A Large Number of Crimes
summary: Something like two million crimes are prevented each year by armed citizens, typically with the display of a firearm with no shots fired.. Ed Shoop writes (Letters, Aug. 13) regarding Alan M. Dershowitz's "A Yellow Light for Red-Flag Laws" (op-ed, Aug. 7) and asks: "Why do we value guns more than each other?" Aside from our constitutional right to have guns, studies have estimated that as many as two million crimes are prevented each year by armed citizens, typically with the display of a firearm with no shots fired. What would be Mr. Shoop's response to the additional two million people a year who will be murdered, raped or robbed because he supported taking away the victims' means of self-protection?

title: Human Error Often the Culprit in Cloud Data Breaches
summary: Mistakes made by customers can often lead to the finger being pointed at cloud providers. Poor security practices, complicated controls and rushed technology programs are causing a rash of data breaches stemming from the use of cloud services, experts say. Both users and cloud providers could be doing more to prevent them.

title: Judges Rule in Favor of New Jersey's Right-to-Die Law

title: Your Watch Says More About Your Status Than You Think
summary: Even in the age of the Apple Watch and casual everything, your timepiece is sending certain signals to colleagues in the know. AN OLD WORKPLACE adage says you shouldn't wear a watch that's fancier than your boss's. For Tony Traina, 27, an associate lawyer in Chicago, however, it would have been difficult to find a more casual timepiece than the $399 Apple Watches his firm's higher-ups tend to favor. He didn't bother. As a watch-lover, he ignored protocol, showing up at work in a $1,500 mechanical watch by German brand Nomos Glashütte. But it barely went noticed.

title: A Danish Villa's Heroic Beginnings
summary: North of Copenhagen in the seaside suburb of Klampenborg, a home whose original owners fled Nazi occupation comes on the market for $2.5 million. A family's dramatic escape from Nazi-occupied Denmark is the back story to a stately suburban villa north of Copenhagen. The two-story, beige-brick home was built by businessman Heinrich Infeld in the 1930s, looked after by friends during World War II, reclaimed by the family after the war, then purchased by his son, who made it his home for six decades. The family retained ownership until five years ago.

title: How to Expertly Pack a Suit So It Doesn't Wrinkle
summary: The head butler at Raffles Singapore shares her technique-and secret weapon-for packing business attire. When packing precious garments, tissue paper is your secret weapon. "You're always trying to minimize creases," said Grace Kiong, head butler at Singapore's storied 132-year-old Raffles Hotel, which reopened this month after a two-year renovation. It's where the Singapore Sling was first slung, and where butlers have been unpacking and packing guests' luggage since the days of corsets and morning coats. The Raffles staff includes some 20 butlers, who, beyond folding guests' unmentionables, provide in-room check-in, run errands (when you anxiously require two backup phone chargers) and memorize guest preferences for everything from vegan snacks to pillow firmness. Ms. Kiong, 34, began her training at Raffles 15 years ago, and is deadly serious about negotiating a suit into a confined space without wrinkles. The keys, she says, are planning, patience and strategic padding.

title: Are Hypnotherapy Apps Better Than Meditation?
summary: Often associated with onstage theatrics and eccentric celebrities, hypnosis is moving further into the mainstream with hypnotherapy apps like Clementine, Harmony Hypnosis and Mindset. Six years ago, Kim Palmer, 40, was working in a senior marketing role at a tech start-up in London, an environment she describes as extremely fast-paced. "I was like a lot of women, probably, very ambitious," she says. "I was work-obsessed; I was a perfectionist." One day at the office, halfway through her pregnancy with her first son, Palmer had a panic attack in front of a group of co-workers. "As someone who took all of their sense of self-worth from being good at work, it was incredibly traumatic for me," she says. She continued to have panic attacks, sometimes in front of her family or friends.

summary: Ethanol companies benefit from fight that pits the Corn Belt against oil, but benefits have limits. The Corn Belt carries a lot of weight in Washington-especially at the moment. That is coming in handy for ethanol companies that have lost some recent rounds to the fossil fuel sector.

title: Hong Kong Clashes Put Brakes on Property Boom
summary: Some analysts now expect home prices, after marching upward for many years, to be flat for 2019. Hong Kong's formidable property market is straining, as protest pressures add to those created by an escalating U.S.-China trade spat and slowing global growth.

title: Investors Betting Against the British Pound Fear a Reversal
summary: U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson's recent Brexit talks prompted a rally in the currency. Some investors are betting that the biggest risk to the British pound isn't that the turmoil around Brexit causes it to plunge further against the dollar, but that it stages an unexpected rally.

title: The Astros' Secret Weapon: Tons of Strikeouts-and Never Striking Out
summary: Houston could become the first team to have the most strikeouts from the mound and the fewest at the plate in the same season since strikeouts were first tracked MLB-wide in 1913. Houston

title: Investor's Ties to WeWork Raise Conflict-of-Interest Concerns
summary: Rhone Group co-founder Steven Langman is one of WeWork's key backers but also runs a fund that leases buildings to the workspace giant. Few people outside of We Co. have more riding on the initial public offering of WeWork's parent company than Steven Langman.

title: Europe's Top Airline is Verboten for Investors
summary: Lufthansa's obsession with protecting its network rather than route profitability is problematic in a slowing European economy. Investors in Europe's biggest airline aren't sitting comfortably in their cabins.

title: Iraq Moves to Pull Plug on Its Iran Power Cord
summary: Under U.S. pressure, Baghdad works to link its energy grid to Arab neighbors, boost its own capacity. BAGHDAD-Iraq is trying to cut its dependence on Iranian energy under pressure from the U.S., moving to connect its power grid to Tehran's Arab rivals and develop alternatives to Iranian natural-gas imports.

title: Great Lakes Cities Gear Up for Winter as Water Levels Rise
summary: Resume Subscription. CHICAGO-A large black drone flew along the city's Lake Michigan shoreline last week, cataloging the damage wrought by the lake's near-record water level: vanished and shrinking beaches, wave-battered homes and crumbling piers.

title: When All-Night Gaming Results in Dropping Out of College
summary: For one young man, videogames helped him deal with anxiety but nearly derailed his college career; how he and his mom fought back. Jake Uskoski was small for his age, stood out for having long hair and got bullied in middle school. "I could count on one hand the number of friends I had," he said.

title: As Automatic Braking Becomes More Common in Cars, So Do Driver Complaints
summary: Technology cuts down on crashes but can also activate when there is no risk; 'I was so scared'. Automatic emergency-braking systems that are promoted as a safety feature in vehicles don't always work as intended and at times activate when there is no risk of a crash, drivers say.

title: A Primer on the Future of Fannie, Freddie
summary: What to expect from the Trump administration's housing-finance overhaul. The Trump administration is close to releasing a blueprint for overhauling Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac , two companies that back half of the nation's $10 trillion mortgage market. The firms have been in government conservatorship since the 2008 financial crisis, and administration officials say it is time to return them to the private sector.

title: Swing-District Democrats Push for Vote on North America Trade Pact
summary: Pact to replace Nafta takes on heightened significance in Texas; Rep. Allred assures business leaders he understands the value of consistency in trade. RICHARDSON, Texas-Tensions over global trade have ramped up the importance of the U.S. trade agreement with Canada and Mexico to businesses in this Dallas suburb-and to the freshman Democratic congressman seeking a second term here.

title: U.S. Plans to Open Direct Talks With Iran-Backed Houthis in Yemen
summary: Washington is looking to prod Saudi Arabia into taking part in secret talks in Oman. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration is preparing to initiate direct talks with Iran-backed Houthi forces in Yemen in an effort to end the four-year-old war, a conflict that has become a volatile front line in the conflict with Tehran, according to people familiar with the plans.

title: Data Center Market Powers Up to Meet Cloud Demand
summary: CONTENT FROM OUR SPONSOR. U.S. companies switching to online software and technology systems are fueling a booming market for computing power.

title: Australian Citizen Arrested in China on Suspicion of Spying
summary: The blogger and spy novelist had been in custody for a half-year. China arrested an Australian writer for alleged spying, Australia's government said, in a case that exacerbates tense relations between the two countries.

title: Johnson & Johnson Ordered to Pay $572 Million in Opioid Case
summary: Verdict caps first case to go to trial among thousands brought by U.S. states, cities against drug industry. An Oklahoma judge ordered Johnson & Johnson to pay $572 million for contributing to the state's opioid-addiction crisis, a verdict that could signal further findings of liability for drug companies as similar cases wind through courts across the country.

title: Ferdinand Piëch, Who Transformed Volkswagen, Dies at 82
summary: Grandson of VW Beetle's original designer helped turn the German auto maker into a global powerhouse. BERLIN-Ferdinand Piëch, grandson of the original designer of the Volkswagen Beetle and a towering figure in modern automotive history, has died, his wife, Ursula Piëch, said Monday.

title: Bristol-Myers Moves Closer to Buying Celgene
summary: Sale of Celgene's skin treatment for $13.4 billion to Amgen seen addressing antitrust concerns from regulators. Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. took a major step toward completing its $74 billion acquisition of Celgene Corp. , as the two pharmaceutical companies found a buyer for a skin treatment whose sale they hope will address antitrust concerns.

title: Trump Softens Tone on China, Iran at G-7 Summit
summary: The president says he thinks China wants to make a deal and indicates he is open to meeting with Iran's president. BIARRITZ, France-President Trump struck a conciliatory tone on the final day of the Group of Seven summit, where he faced pressure from French President Emmanuel Macron to de-escalate the trade war with China and ease tensions with Iran.
